Lists physics objects added to the physics scene
A static rigid body. Not affected by collisions with other objects or by gravity.
A dynamic rigid body. Will deform when hit by other objects. Affected by gravity and will fall freely.
A soft body. Cloth-like objects with no volume are also soft bodies.
Treated as a sphere for collision detection.
Treated as a box for collision detection.
Treated as a capsule for collision detection. The longest axis is used as the height of the bounding box.
Treated as a mesh for collision detection.
Establishes a thickness for a physics object. If a soft body slips through other objects, add a margin.
Turn on when specifying sphere-like polygon meshes for soft bodies. Turn off for cloth-like flat surfaces or polygon meshes with no thickness.
The degree that adjacent vertices of a soft body stick together. Larger values result in less deformation.
Preserves the original shape of a soft body that has volume. Larger values result in less deformation. Values too large will result in divergence.
Adds the selected object(s) to the physics scene. The position of objects and the elapsed time of the physics scene will be reset.
Updates the information of the physics object selected in the listbox. The position of objects and the elapsed time of the physics scene will be reset.
Removes the physics object selected in the listbox. The position of objects and the elapsed time of the physics scene will be reset.
Displays the total elapsed time of the physics scene
Specifies the length of time to advance when stepping forward
Stops the physics calculation when there is a collision with a rigid body. Turn off to restart the calculation. This option does not affect soft body collisions.
Resets the elapsed time of the physics scene. Physics objects will return to their original positions.
Steps backward the specified length of time.
Steps forward the specified length of time.
Converts the physics object to a real object. The original object is hidden.
Cancel the calculation
